sections: Let me start off by thanking everyone who responded to our

last week — we got so many great responses and it has really helped us. We are trying to expand our coverage as we head into the final weeks of the election, and your support is helping make that possible. And if you didn’t see our original ask,
to see three ways you can still help.

Last week was one of the most intense weeks of political news I’ve ever seen. It was just endless news every minute of the day. I don’t even know how to organize my thoughts after it, other than to just offer up some random takeaways.

First and foremost, the Senate has to halt the Supreme Court confirmation. The entire process is not only illegitimate, it is now wildly unsafe. The U.S. Capitol is a hot zone. Are we really going to see lawmakers on the floor of the Senate in

Of course, Mitch McConnell says he is moving forward. That’s hardly surprising — for McConnell, every single day is Game of Thrones. This is why in the battle for power and policy, mcConnell typically wins and Democrats typically lose. Jed Bartlet isn’t coming to save us.

Expecting McConnell and the Republicans will make responsible decisions seems silly. They aren’t going to refrain from holding floor votes out of some humanistic desire to avoid knowingly infecting other lawmakers and staff. They just do not care. They are T-1000 Terminators for a corporate agenda.
All of that means Democrats are going to have to use all of their power if there is any hope to stop the nomination. And we will be covering that story.

Speaking of coverage, we’ve been breaking really big stories — and when you look at the clips below, keep in mind that all those stories are being produced by a small team. I’m really proud of what we’ve been able to do.

I’ve worked in journalism for many years, and I have found this political and media environment to be among the most challenging I’ve ever faced. It’s difficult to know how to deploy limited reporting resources and which stories to focus on when there is just so much happening. We always want and need your input — so don’t hesitate to send me an email.

One thing I can say: when we make story selection decisions, we always try to follow the money and the power — and we couldn’t do it without your support. Your subscription is giving us the resources to do this work and make the impact we’re making. As always, thank you for being part of our team.
Stuff The Daily Poster reported this week:
Shut Down The Supreme Court Confirmation. Right Now.
Amazon COVID Outbreak Followed Trump Officials Helping Bezos Block Worker Safety Initiative
Fossil Fuel Companies Profited, Now We Owe Billions
Billionaire GOP Donor’s Firm Reports Sub-Zero Tax Rate
We Still Don’t Know Who Is Paying For Trump’s SCOTUS Seats
The Two Huge Questions About Trump's Tax Returns
I Note The Absence Of A Quorum
A primer on the procedural tactics Democrats could employ to try to stop Trump’s Supreme Court nominee.
A Pro-Trump Militant Group Has Recruited Thousands of Police, Soldiers, and Veterans

“What would happen, I wondered, if Trump lost, said the election had been stolen, and refused to concede? Or the flip side: What if he won and his opponents poured into the streets in protest? The U.S. was already seeing a surge in political violence, and in August the FBI put out a bulletin that warned of a possible escalation heading into the election. How much worse would things get if trained professionals took up arms?”
Trump Is Trying To Split Biden From The Left. Don't Let Him.

“All the talking heads missed a key element of Trump's strategy: he repeatedly tried to bait Biden into repudiating the left in an attempt to fracture the Democratic vote. Trump may be the most disastrous and destructive president in modern American history, but he is not an idiot and those who treat him like he is do so at their own peril.”
“Both political parties in the US believe the other side is plotting a takeover of the nation that will end American democracy. The panic, fear, ranting and scolding has reached unbearable levels.”
After Dakota Access CEO Gave $10M, Trump Pushed Secret Pipeline Permits
An important story about the swamp.
In the 2020 Election, Journalists Need An Agenda: Defending Democracy
“When politicians competing for votes float poisonous charges without even a modicum of evidence, self-respecting journalists have to push back in some way.”
Peak Newsletter? That Was 80 Years Ago
Newsletters like this one are part of a movement to build a whole new media. But this isn’t the first time there has been a challenge to corporate news organizations.
— I was on Josh Fox’s great YouTube show to discuss the election and how progressives should think about the general election.
